content.raw:
The "about point" must also be specified for completeness \(otherwise we could have completely different numbers\).  
Looking at the source code it'd seem this is with respect to the center of mass?

If that's the case I'd suggest this reading as: "Returns the mass matrix computed about the center of mass of the link it corresponds to and expressed in the inertial frame of that link"

content.raw:
We must be very specific about the "about point" \(the point about which the inertia matrix gets computed, a geometric concept, independent of the frame in which we compute these numbers\) and the "expressed-in" frame \(which says in what frame we actually compute doubles we can put in a matrix\). Leaving it up to the user will always lead to errors. Two different users can always interpret this in different ways and that defeats the very purpose of having a specification. So in my IMO these SDF objects should provide an invariant that the sdformat library promises to keep. For instance \(I believe that was your intention\) that this inertia matrix always is compute about the COM and always is expressed in the frame of the corresponding link. This, irrespective of how a user might have written the SDF file \(which me, as a user of sdformat, have no way to know\).  
  
Therefore, I propose this reads more like "Returns the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link."  
  
Does this make sense at all?
content.html:
We must be very specific about the "about point" (the point about which the inertia matrix gets computed, a geometric concept, independent of the frame in which we compute these numbers) and the "expressed-in" frame (which says in what frame we actually compute doubles we can put in a matrix). Leaving it up to the user will always lead to errors. Two different users can always interpret this in different ways and that defeats the very purpose of having a specification. So in my IMO these SDF objects should provide an invariant that the sdformat library promises to keep. For instance (I believe that was your intention) that this inertia matrix always is compute about the COM and always is expressed in the frame of the corresponding link. This, irrespective of how a user might have written the SDF file (which me, as a user of sdformat, have no way to know).

Therefore, I propose this reads more like "Returns the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link."

Does this make sense at all?

content.raw:
> and always is expressed in the frame of the corresponding link.

It seems like it is actually expressed in the "inertia frame" of this `Inertia` object, which is offset from the "link frame" by the transform returned by `this->Pose()`.

I think the wording of the documentation here is a bit misleading, because the translational component of the "Pose of an Inertial object" is definitely meant to refer to the center of mass location with respect to the link frame. However, the rotational component of the "Pose of an Inertial object" is definitely arbitrary and user-defined. So maybe we should clarify that here.
content.html:
and always is expressed in the frame of the corresponding link.

It seems like it is actually expressed in the "inertia frame" of this Inertia object, which is offset from the "link frame" by the transform returned by this->Pose().

I think the wording of the documentation here is a bit misleading, because the translational component of the "Pose of an Inertial object" is definitely meant to refer to the center of mass location with respect to the link frame. However, the rotational component of the "Pose of an Inertial object" is definitely arbitrary and user-defined. So maybe we should clarify that here.

content.raw:
This library is not directly tied to SDF and the math library lacks the concept of links. The sdf library has chosen to use the Inertial class, but a downstream package (sdformat) should not dictate how an upstream package (math) is used.

The line "Returns the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link." would be confusing because there are no links. The link could be changed to "For example, SDF makes use of Inertia and has chosen to interpret the return value of this function as the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link."
content.html:
This library is not directly tied to SDF and the math library lacks the concept of links. The sdf library has chosen to use the Inertial class, but a downstream package (sdformat) should not dictate how an upstream package (math) is used.

The line "Returns the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link." would be confusing because there are no links. The link could be changed to "For example, SDF makes use of Inertia and has chosen to interpret the return value of this function as the inertia matrix for a link as computed about the center of mass of that link and expressed in the frame of that same link."

content.raw: Update the documentation here: ef1dac0
content.html: Update the documentation here: ef1dac0

content.raw:
There were some discussions [1] in the past about the possible confusion between the "inertial frame" in Gazebo sense (the frame in which the link inertia is expressed) and the "inertial frame" in the classical Newtonian physics sense (a frame in which Newton's First Law holds). I wonder if a specific documentation note could make sense to avoid to confuse the users. 

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1456/implemented-addlinkforce-for-ode-with/diff#comment-5379775
content.html:
There were some discussions [1] in the past about the possible confusion between the "inertial frame" in Gazebo sense (the frame in which the link inertia is expressed) and the "inertial frame" in the classical Newtonian physics sense (a frame in which Newton's First Law holds). I wonder if a specific documentation note could make sense to avoid to confuse the users.

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1456/implemented-addlinkforce-for-ode-with/diff#comment-5379775

content.raw:
I know now where my confusion starts. It’s here in this constructor and in the class’s documentation. I believe that what we’d like to accomplish is to be very specific about what this class does. Let me give it a try for this constructor and correct me please if I am wrong:  
”Constructs an inertial object from the mass matrix for a body B, about its center of mass Bcm, and expressed in a frame that we’ll call the “inertial” frame Bi, i.e. the frame in which the components of the mass matrix are specified \(see this class’s documentation for details\). The pose object specifies the pose X\_FBi of the inertial frame Bi in the frame F. of this inertial object \(see class’s documentation\).”
content.html:
I know now where my confusion starts. It’s here in this constructor and in the class’s documentation. I believe that what we’d like to accomplish is to be very specific about what this class does. Let me give it a try for this constructor and correct me please if I am wrong:
”Constructs an inertial object from the mass matrix for a body B, about its center of mass Bcm, and expressed in a frame that we’ll call the “inertial” frame Bi, i.e. the frame in which the components of the mass matrix are specified (see this class’s documentation for details). The pose object specifies the pose X_FBi of the inertial frame Bi in the frame F. of this inertial object (see class’s documentation).”

content.raw: Thanks, updated: f45b7cf
content.html: Thanks, updated: f45b7cf

content.raw:
To be consistent with the constructor’s documentation, I’d believe we’d like something like:

“The %Inertial object provides a representation for the mass and inertia matrix of a body B. The components of the inertia matrix are expressed in what we call the “inertial” frame Bi of the body, i.e. the frame in which these inertia components are measured. The inertial frame Bi must be located at the center of mass of the body, but not necessarily aligned with the body’s frame. In addition, this class allows users to specify a frame F for these inertial properties by specifying the pose X\_FBi of the inertial frame Bi in the frame inertial object frame F.”
content.html:
To be consistent with the constructor’s documentation, I’d believe we’d like something like:

“The %Inertial object provides a representation for the mass and inertia matrix of a body B. The components of the inertia matrix are expressed in what we call the “inertial” frame Bi of the body, i.e. the frame in which these inertia components are measured. The inertial frame Bi must be located at the center of mass of the body, but not necessarily aligned with the body’s frame. In addition, this class allows users to specify a frame F for these inertial properties by specifying the pose X_FBi of the inertial frame Bi in the frame inertial object frame F.”

content.raw:
This method is really mystifying to me. Does it really get used somewhere?  
Maybe I am not understanding what this class represents at all?  
Lets see…. what does  the rotation `_q` represent? a new rotation `q_GBi` of the frame Bi respect to a new frame G? if so, why would I change the stored matrix? it’d seem this method is trying to keep as an invariant, the matrix expressed in the F frame, rather than in the Bi frame \(which is the actual physical frame here\). Wouldn’t we like the mass matrix in the Bi frame to stay untouched for the lifetime of this class?

content.raw: I do like it. If I understand it correctly, then this class is a container for the inertia matrix about Bcm and expressed in the inertial frame Bi and, for a pose X\_FBi on some frame F that relates to a particular instance of this class \(for instance to the body frame B when parsing\). If that’s it, then yes I like it!
